title: 106_s2217
content: The Act may be cited as the "National Museum of the American Indian Commemorative Coin Act of 2000" or the "American Buffalo Coin Commemorative Coin Act of 2000". The Smithsonian Institution, established in 1846 with funds from James Smithson, plays a vital role in developing the national identity of the United States. It is the world's largest museum complex, visited by millions annually. The National Museum of the American Indian (NMAI) was established in 1989 by an Act of Congress. The National Museum of the American Indian (NMAI) was established by an Act of Congress in 1989 (Public Law 101-185) with the purpose of advancing the study of Native Americans, collecting, preserving, and exhibiting Native American objects, and providing research and study programs. The NMAI works in cooperation with Native Americans, overseeing a collection spanning over 10,000 years of American history, and is located near the United States Capitol on the National Mall. The National Museum of the American Indian (NMAI) is set to open in 2002, with a commemorative coin featuring a Native American and buffalo design to raise funds for its opening. The NMAI is set to open in 2002, and a commemorative coin featuring a Native American and buffalo design will raise funding for its opening and support its endowment and educational outreach funds. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $1 silver coins in commemoration of the opening of the Museum of the American Indian. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper. They will be legal tender and the silver for minting them can be obtained from various sources. The design of the $1 coins minted under this Act is based on the original 5-cent buffalo nickel by James Earle Fraser. Each coin features a Native American profile on the obverse side and an American buffalo on the reverse side. The coins also include inscriptions of the coin's value, the year "2001", and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design for the coins will be selected by the Secretary after consultation. The design for the $1 coins minted under this Act shall be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities. Only 1 facility of the United States Mint may be used to strike any particular quality of the coins minted under this Act, with preference for the Denver facility. The Secretary may issue coins beginning on January 1, 2001, and minting must cease after December 31, 2001. SEC. 7. SALE OF COINS. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price including the face value, a surcharge, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a discount as well. All sales will include a $10 surcharge per coin. The proceeds from surcharges on coins sold under this Act will be promptly paid to the National Museum of the American Indian for commemorating its opening and supporting its endowment and educational outreach funds. The museum will be subject to audit requirements for the received amounts. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure minting coins won't cost the government. Coins can only be issued if payment is received, security is provided, or a guarantee of payment from a qualified institution is given.
